/                                ← The root directory (top of the entire filesystem)
├── bin                          ← Essential commands used by the system
│     (Examples: ls, cp, mv, rm, cat)
│
├── boot                         ← Files needed to start (boot) Linux
│     (Examples: Linux kernel vmlinuz, GRUB bootloader files)
│
├── dev                          ← Device files representing hardware
│     (Examples: /dev/sda = SSD/HDD, /dev/tty = terminal, /dev/null = data sink)
│
├── etc                          ← System configuration files
│     (Examples: /etc/hosts, /etc/passwd, /etc/ssh/sshd_config)
│
├── home                         ← Home directories for normal users
│   ├── user1                    ← user1’s personal files
│   │       (Examples: Documents, Downloads, .bashrc)
│   └── user2                    ← user2’s personal files
│           (Same structure as user1)
│
├── root                         ← Home directory of the root (administrator) user
│     (Example: root's .bashrc, root-only scripts)
│
├── tmp                          ← Temporary files (often deleted on reboot)
│     (Examples: temp files created by applications, installer data)
│
├── usr                          ← Applications, libraries, documentation, etc.
│   ├── bin                      ← Executable programs for users
│   │       (Examples: python, gcc, nano, vim)
│   ├── lib                      ← Shared libraries used by programs
│   │       (Examples: libpython3.12.so, libssl.so)
│   └── share                    ← Architecture-independent data
│           (Examples: icons, fonts, man pages)
│
└── var                          ← Variable files (change frequently)
    ├── log                      ← Log files
    │       (Examples: syslog, auth.log, nginx/access.log)
    ├── lib                      ← Service/application data
    │       (Examples: databases, Docker state, apt data)
    └── cache                    ← Cached data
            (Examples: package manager caches, thumbnail cache)
